natural problem: Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = \sin (3x - \pi).$
natural solution: Since the graph of $y = \sin (3x - \pi)$ is the same as the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the right, the phase shift is $\boxed{\frac{\pi}{3}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros; size(400);

real g(real x) { 	return sin(3*x - pi); } real f(real x) { 	return sin(3*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-2,2,pi/2,1);
layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy] Note that we can also shift the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the left, so an answer of $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{3}}$ is also acceptable.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sin (3 * x - pi)"
shows  "phase_shift f = - pi / 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = \sin (3x - \pi).$ The final Answer is -\frac{\pi}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the graph of $y = \sin (3x - \pi)$ is the same as the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the right, the phase shift is $\boxed{\frac{\pi}{3}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros; size(400);
 real g(real x) { 	return sin(3*x - pi); } real f(real x) { 	return sin(3*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-2,2,pi/2,1);
 layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy] Note that we can also shift the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the left, so an answer of $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{3}}$ is also acceptable.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sin (3 * x - pi)"
shows  "phase_shift f = - pi / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "What is the phase shift of the function $f(x) = \sin(3x - \pi)$? The final answer is $-\pi/3$."

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sin (3 * x - pi)"
and h1 : "\<exists> a. \<forall> x. f (x + a) = f x"
shows  "a = -pi / 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = \sin (3x - \pi).$ The final Answer is -\frac{\pi}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the graph of $y = \sin (3x - \pi)$ is the same as the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the right, the phase shift is $\boxed{\frac{\pi}{3}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros; size(400);
 real g(real x) { 	return sin(3*x - pi); } real f(real x) { 	return sin(3*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-2,2,pi/2,1);
 layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy] Note that we can also shift the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the left, so an answer of $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{3}}$ is also acceptable.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sin (3 * x - pi)"
and h1 : "\<exists> a. \<forall> x. f (x + a) = f x"
shows  "a = -pi / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of $a$ such that the function $f(x) = \sin(3x - \pi)$ satisfies the property $f(x+a) = f(x)$. The final answer is $-\frac{\pi}{3}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sin (3 * x - pi)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y = f x"
shows  "y has_phase_shift -pi / 3"

 layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy] Note that we can also shift the graph of $y = \sin 3x$ $\frac{\pi}{3}$ units to the left, so an answer of $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{3}}$ is also acceptable.
 *)

fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sin (3 * x - pi)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. y = f x"
shows  "y has_phase_shift -pi / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

fixes x :: real and y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

 *)

shows  "y (x + pi / 3) = y x"
